subsection_content_1: Following an announcement last week that H5N1 had been detected in the district of Thung Saliam, the deaths of 30 chickens, which died November 11th, were reported in nearby Sukhothai, Sawankhalok District. These mortalities sparked fears of bird flu spreading in the central province of Sukhothai. The birds were promptly buried and another 385 chickens from 28 households were rounded up in preparation for culling.
subsection_content_4: H5N1 has been ruled out as the cause of death in a man from Bandung last week.  The man, who worked as a chicken slaughterer, died from respiratory complications and symptoms of pneumonia, but did not test positive for bird flu after extensive analyses. The head of Hasan Sadikin Hospital, Cissy Kartasamita, said the man's respiratory problems were not caused by bird flu, "but the cause is yet to be determined as we need time to conclude the cause."
subsection_content_3: An eight-year old boy has been infected with H5N1, the Egyptian Ministry of Health has announced. The boy, a resident of Fayum, had a high fever, respiratory difficulties and was initially treated at a local hospital before being transferred to a specialty hospital in Cairo on November 8th. Abdel Rahman Shaheen, a spokesman for the Health Ministry, said the boy was exposed to the virus by infected poultry.
subsection_content_5: A girl from Semarang, Central Java, who died November 7th, may have been infected with bird flu. Her doctor and a member of the hospital's avian influenza team, Agus Suryanto, said the girl died of respiratory failure and a high (39ºC) fever after 10 days of hospitalization. "There was a chance that she got infected by bird flu as she had been living nearby a chicken abattoir," Agus said. Tatik Suryanti, the local health agency chief, said that tests at two laboratories have confirmed the girl had H5N1. However, the case is officially being denied by the Health Minister, Siti Fadilah Supari, who says "Both of the laboratory tests showed that she was negative of bird flu, so the total death toll (of bird flu) remains 112." The disagreement highlights the continued dispute between Indonesia and the World Health Organization over the sharing of influenza samples.
subsection_header_5: H5N1 has been ruled out as the cause of death in a man from Bandung last week.  The man, who worked as a chicken slaughterer, died from respiratory complications and symptoms of pneumonia, but did not test positive for bird flu after extensive analyses. The head of Hasan Sadikin Hospital, Cissy Kartasamita, said the man's respiratory problems were not caused by bird flu, "but the cause is yet to be determined as we need time to conclude the cause."
subsection_content_2: Bird flu has been confirmed by The Provincial People's Committee of Nghe An as the cause of an outbreak in Nghe An, Dien Chau District, where nearly 1,200 birds died over the last two weeks. The outbreak occurred at a farm in Dien Hong commune which housed 1,400 chickens and ducks, where some of the birds have tested positive for H5N1, according to the province's Animal Health Department.
